title: [INTRO] James "Statikk" Bach - Champion Update Design Lead
body:
Greetings friends,

I’m James Bach, but you guys probably better know me by “Statikk.” I studied Neuroscience and Computer Science during college, both of which I probably don’t utilize nearly enough. Ever since graduating 5 and a half years ago, I’ve had the privilege to work here at Riot on League. I started out in QA, eventually found myself in Design, led the Live Gameplay team for several years, and now I’m getting the opportunity to lead the Champion Update team. 

To me, gaming isn’t just a hobby, it’s a lifestyle. I prefer games that allow you to deeply invest into them, and that ultimately reward you with awesome, memorable experiences when you do so. Some people would also say I really just like games with “phat loot,” which I really can’t deny. Before joining Riot, I played Call of Duty 1 and 2 competitively, dueled countless others in Diablo 2, and placed in the top 10 during LoL’s beta before release.

Outside of games, I am big into music and hip hop dance. I am also infamously overly invested into KPop.

**WHAT AM I DOING AT RIOT? WHAT CAN YOU EXPECT NEXT YEAR?**
This year, I focused on doing some of the larger-scale reworks including Gangplank, Darius, Miss Fortune, and Corki (I know some of you already have your pitchforks out - sorry!). Going into the next year, I’ll be stepping into a leadership role on the Champion Update team, helping set the vision for which champions we work on and helping guide the designers on the team to ensure that we consistently deliver faithful reworks that don’t just simply change a champion, but rather enhance who they are.

Outside of individual champions, the Champion Update team has also done a lot of work to better identify and categorize the classes of champions that actually exist in LoL. As League and our shared understand of the game has matured, the generic vocabulary and concepts we used have (until recently)  somehow stayed exactly the same (“Fighter,” “Mage,” etc.). Terms like the “Juggernaut” originate from the team’s analysis across the entire roster of champions, and we’re looking to continue to expand upon these class definitions in the coming year.

**WHAT AM I GOING TO TALK ABOUT?**
I will largely be focusing on each of the individual reworks we've recently released and the ones we plan to release in the coming year. Specifically, we want to continue to give you guys more insight into who we’re working on, why we’re working on them, and where we think we succeeded and failed on each project after they’ve had time to breathe on the live servers. You may also see posts from me talking a bit more in-depth about our updated perspectives on the champion classes as we continue to define and explore our roster.

**WHAT WOULD YOU LIKE TO HEAR FROM ME?**
This is definitely an open question that I’d be interested to know about. I’ve experienced a ton of League as it has evolved over its history, so I feel I can provide pretty broad insights about the game as a whole. Hopefully you guys give me easy questions, but you probably won't. =/

replies.body:
Do you feel like Mordekaiser's rework was a success and that you're able to balance him accordingly for the longer term?

How about his thematics, does he really fit the vision of an undead General bent on eternal Conquest?

I personally think he doesn't really live up to his expectations and that he's got a LOT of potential that's simply left untapped due to him having received a pretty low scale rework instead of a full blown one that would have explored his themes and really made him a character befitting the title of Iron Revenant.


What's your personal opinion on the matter and would it be too crazy to assume he'd be on that fabled rework list once more?

Hopefully we largely addressed this with the previous Morde threads, but I'll reiterate again. I think we can all agree that the Morde rework wasn't our best work from several different angles. We probably didn't get enough benefit out of the cost of changes we incurred here. Still stand by our position, that he is ultimately healthier and will continue to be tweaked towards the duo lane at least for the short term. I agree that long term, we probably need to revisit Morde and do a full overhaul, but that's probably far in the future unfortunately.

Welp, that's a bitter pill to swallow.

Still, does this mean Mordekaiser won't at least be getting a VU in the near future? He's still got the same rig from five years ago and is really showing his age.

I'm just going to add on to this...

I really do believe that the only way that Mordekaiser can ever be balanced is through a TRUE rework, something similar to Sion/Poppy. There's just no way to balance an only-damage champion like him. If he's behind, he's useless. If he's ahead, he's incredibly difficult to kill. 

There's never an in-between with Mordekaiser. If possible, I think he should be added to the rework list, but Sion-sized rework.

Could you give us the "grades" that Riot thinks the reworks have updated on the most recent updates? Ie, C > B, C > A, ect...

Gangplank
Fiora
Darius
Garen
Skarner
Morde

I really wish I could answer this in earnest, but I think just giving any of them a letter grade would be misrepresenting the work. Every project has its successes and failures, and the follow-up reviews we've been releasing are hopefully making that more transparent to you guys. It'd be very biased and unrepresentative of our team's actual analysis if I simply just gave them a letter grade.

But that's the issue. We see from some Reds that "Skarner was a success". Others "Skarner missed the mark a bit". 

WE don't know what the Riot views as success here. It seems like Riot's view of success is vastly different than the players. If we can't/are not allowed to know if something "worked", then how are we to know the goals that were set. Things like "healthier" doesn't answer the question. Look at Morde, instead of making a negative impact on 1/2 players a game, it's now 3/4 players a game. He's not healthier now. Otherwise we would see him played/winning more. 

So either Morde was a failure, or he was a success. And the second answer being Riots view makes me worry.

There are points of success and of failures. It is meaningless to say "it' s good/it's bad" overall, because it values nothing and does not bring any value to the table.

For example, Morde. Many things they did with him were very very good, but with some critical failures that made him crash. Now, if the goods > failures but the failures are critical, does that mean it is a "good" rework?
That's my question. Did the re-works succeed at the goals Riot wished for. And if they say a blanket "yes" then I am disappointing in them.

But then you have to specify on what regard they were successfull, or at least ask which domains does he think were noteworthy.

For example, did the Mordekaiser minirework succeed in enriching the botlane champion choice of the game? Yes!
Did it so the single experience itself is good? Not very much. Or just not at all.

There are different faces and values to consider, both pratical and theorical. I am just suggesting you to be more precise.

Ghostcrawler recent posted in his ask.fm that he had talked with the "design leads" about what they thought of what happens when an update goes 'halfway', in his words, gets a Champ from being a C to a B when the goal is an A. There apparently was consensus that it is better to then move on to other champs. What are your thoughts on this and why? 

I found his trust argument lacking. I have a lot more trust towards following through on work and finishing a job instead of leaving it half done, for (let's be honest) years at a time. Cass, in the opinion of the design team from what I understand, moved from a C to a B. For me she moved from a C+/B- to whatever grade champs I don't want to play are (F?). She isn't going to get any more work probably until 2017 with the focus on Yorick, Taric (both justified) and Shen (not so much).

You can find the post in here a few questions down:

https://m.ask.fm/RiotGhostcrawler

I'm still with Ghostcrawler on this one.

We should be prioritizing whatever work delivers the most value to the game, so if we get a champion from a C to a B, even if we were shooting for an A, that champion is still better off than the other champions who are still C's.

Trust me, it doesn't feel good to leave work in a non-ideal state, but that's an honest part of any job. We need to be constantly questioning our prioritization and focuses.

The ideal state is to just consistently execute on getting champions to A's or at least as close as possible. We need to be smarter in deciding upfront how much work it would take to get a given project to an A, and simply avoid ones that we don't feel are feasible given the scope of the project.

The problem with what I understand with Cass from other players and what I know from the rework of Mordekaiser isn't that they are left in a healthier state, but left in a state where people who played them before don't want to play them. This is as big of a problem as the health of a champion. And probably the bigger problem is they are left in a still, at least, a somewhat unhealthy state. So the champion is stuck in a kind of unhealthy state for at least a year (probably longer) where people who enjoyed playing them before don't want to play them.

This is like replacing the bags of potato chips in a lunch line with salads with ranch dressing. But what's the point of replacing the chips with the salads if nobody buys the salads and the salads are only a little bit healthier than the chips. In effect you are providing negative value by not fixing this. <- This actually happened at the cafeteria in the building I used to work in.

Right, an "A" project is both faithful to mains of the champion while also appealing to new players who the champions used to not appeal to. 

Sometimes though, it's still possible to take a "C" project to a "B" by creating a new version that appeals to a new audience but disappoints past players of the champion. It's non-ideal surely, but it is sometimes where we land.

What new audience?

Cass' pick rate isn't any better then it is pre-rework. I think it's worse, even.

This is a tricky conversation that has 2 parts:

1) We can't judge the success of a project purely off the raw pick rate of a champion. Even then like I said before, we can all agree that the Cassiopeia rework was not a success, and it shows.

2) Cass' new playstyle may not appeal to you personally or any of the old Cassiopeia players, but it is flatly incorrect to say that it doesn't appeal to some amount of players.

Once again, I have made no comments specifically on whether Cassiopeia went from a "C" to a "B" or what not. These were all theoretical.

Yes, we are in agreement. We internally are also not happy with Cassiopeia's current state. This is not a guarantee that she'll be getting work done, but it does mean we think we can get a lot of value by re-visiting her.

>This is not a guarantee that she'll be getting work done

That's the worst possible answer you could have given, and let me explain you why.

Imagine you had a valuable vase, one that's very precious to you. One day a guy comes by your house, while sporting a t-shirt with a fistbump symbol on it, just to break into your place and wreck that vase. He proceeds to leave without responding to your complaints and demands for compensation just to ocassionaly drop by again while still refusing to man up for the mess he's done. Fast forward an entire season and you're still left with a broken vase and this guy comes by and says he'll probably won't be able to make it up to you, not even in the near future. Heck, the guy even refuses to repay you a fraction of the lost value - he just leaves and buys himself a new vase.

Do you realize how messed up this entire situation is? Do you know how disrespectful your behavior appears to ANYONE who considers themselves a Cass veteran?

How do you guys feel about Sona. (even although that's a fairly old rework) I think this is probably one of the only reworks that's actually made a champion considerably worse to play, along with Cass's.

I'm not saying that you should judge a rework's success based on pick rate, or that there are no fans of new Cass.

I am saying that I doubt that very many  people decided to play Cass due to the rework.

> [{quoted}](name=Statikk,realm=NA,application-id=A7LBtoKc,discussion-id=VyuLdWhd,comment-id=0014000100000001,timestamp=2015-12-18T19:12:02.621+0000)

> Sometimes though, it's still possible to take a "C" project to a "B" by creating a new version that appeals to a new audience but disappoints past players of the champion. It's non-ideal surely, but it is sometimes where we land.

I think you misunderstood what I was trying to say. What I was trying to say is the team took a champion (mordekaiser for example) that was admittedly unhealthy, but had a small, but dedicated group of players who played him, and made him slightly less unhealthy, but now no one really wants to play him.

I forget which rioter it was that said it, but in response to a support player saying that they found it unfun to support Morde, xe admitted that Morde in his current state is unfun to play as, with, and against. To me, this seems worse than just being a little more unhealthy, but fun to play as.

I don't think I misunderstood in this case. I think the part we're disagreeing on is that "no one really wants to play him." There are a lot of reasons why a champion's play rate can be low - they could be severely undertuned, they could have a baseline unappealing archetype, it could also be that their gameplay is just not fun. I feel it's easy to jump quickly to the conclusion that it's always the gameplay that is the core reason - and in many cases it may have a large impact but it certainly isn't always the primary reason.

It's important to not confuse your personal opinion and use it as representative of literally every other player's opinion.

I think it's also easy to look back and overrate how "interesting" or "fun" a champion was before we did work on them. In my opinion, Morde has never really met the bar of being objectively fun to play as (especially compared to modern standards). I really don't think we made him less fun - our big fault is that we failed to move the needle and make him undoubtedly more fun.

But that's the problem - there *were* people who found Morde fun to play. And when you have designers who don't understand why people play or like champs or find champs fun, you end up with bad reworks

Well I'm not talking about playrate. I was a Poppy main before the rework, so I know all about low playrate does not mean not fun as old Poppy was really fun to play as. What I'm talking about is that before, yes a lot of people didn't exactly like playing him, but there was some that did. Now I haven't talked to a single person I know, or have really seen any posts, or really any comment anywhere saying that they enjoy the new Mordekaiser. Yes, I know the lack of seeing such comments does not mean these new Morde lovers don't exist. I am sure they do. And statistically they must. And there are some really cool and fun things about new Morde, like Ghost Dragon. But when in general the overwhelming people in a game don't enjoy having the champion in their game whether it is on their team (i.e. supports supporting morde), the enemy, or the morde player itself, this speaks to a bigger issue.

Also a little off topic, but from my perspective I don't find most of the new champions that have come out fun to play as. So I'm not the biggest fan of the modern standards of fun (yes I understand that this might be tainting my position in this Morde/Cass discussion, but I am trying my best to be neutral - probably failing though). In general new champions are too bloated mechanically or have a mini game which I don't like. I prefer simple champions that are more point and click and have very grokable power. In fact only two of my commonly played champions over the years haven't been significantly reworked in some way - Leona and Nasus. The rest - AP Yi, Gragas, Garen, Morde, Poppy, Zilean - have all been changed in some pretty big ways. And out of all those the only one that I still enjoy playing is Poppy.

I'm rather interested then what the numbers will show next patch with W on Allied minions becoming a thing.  My _hunch_ is a significant drop in duo lane mordekaiser play.  

But that's biiiig speculation,
I don't think his win rate will go up significantly though seeing that his problem is being a DPS damage source who's not durable enough to get things done if not ahead.

For me, I feel like the attitude they have really resembles contempt. GC talked about the fact that very few people complain about the rework, since ambivalent don't speak up. But I don't think it's actually logical to consider ambivalent people as positive. If you gave a shiny new toy to someone and he's ambivalent, you clearly did something wrong.

He also brings Poppy, where he says that leaving Poppy in the dust for years doesn't hurt many people so its not that bad, but that's a skewed way of looking at it. The question should rather be how many people are fine with Poppy as-is, vs how many people want her to change. Once again, undecided people can't be used as a positive or a negative, they're ambivalent. In this case, I see a lot of people finding the rework "look nice", "feel nice", etc. but I haven't seen many people suddenly decide to main Poppy. Sure, she may have 8-10x more games played... but 80% of those are played by people having at most 15 games played on Poppy. To me, it feels like Poppy was simply deserted by the Poppy lovers which really shouldn't happen.

I agree. I don't think Riot takes reworks seriously enough. When a rework fails, the champ is moved to the bottom of the list and won't see anything for years. Cass' "rework" was at the end of 2014. She will be lucky to see anything by 2017. It seems like Riot is saying, ah well, it's just one playerbase. We did something so it looks like we are going through the list of bad champs and fixing them and overall people like it is incredibly rude if Riot is claiming that the size of a playerbase doesn't matter. It most obviously does.

There is a reason that Lee Sin mains can get nerfs reverted by complaining loudly enough that Riot posts about it but Cass players can have 6 months of silence where they think she is still being reworked (because they were told she was) when nothing is actually happening. It's all in the size of the playerbase. 

"When you burn a Cass main, you may cause a huge drop in trust for Cass mains but it's not going to affect that many players overall"

EDIT: Clarity
Hi there. :) Any possible insight you may give about the {{champion:51}}  VU? I want to see her update more than anyone else's. Can we expect it for sometime 2016, maybe?

We're shying away from pure visual updates in the near future. We feel we get so much more value out of combining gameplay and visual updates - executing on both at the same time. I'll go find out where exactly Caitlyn lies on the art quality spectrum, but I suspect she's not too close to the bottom.
How does this affect someone like Cho, who is supposed to get a thematic/visual update but who doesn't need any work on his kit?

Who's idea was it initially to have Gangplank "die" and be disabled (to further this question: Who came up with the idea of revealing his Captain skin as his initial base skin and then after his death to reveal his actual rework base)? I love his rework and was a bit disappointed when I saw I couldn't play him for a bit. :P

In terms of gameplay - where there any times where you have completely swapped out either Q, W, or R, or did you guys always know you were just refining those abilities and just mainly changing his E? Also what other iterations had Gangplanks E gone through before becoming the chaining barrels we see today? :O

Regardless, thanks for creating my relatively new main. :D

I honestly forget who exactly was the originator of the GP death idea. Sometimes ideas like that get said once in a meeting and then generate a lot of excitement across the entire team. We were all definitely nervous about disabling him for a significant period of time, but hopefully it worked out for the better.

We were pretty happy with GP's Q and W from the get-go. I actually had done explorations into completely new R's that actually brought down Cannons (and at one point it summoned what I referred to as the Pirate Gundam) that were used to split push and apply global pressure. Unfortunately, we ended up canning all of these ideas for 1 reason or another.

Gangplank's E honestly was always a barrel though it started out much simpler. Most of the work on his E came in the bells and whistles - allowing them to be targetable by enemies and sorting out the delayed-chaining mechanism and the like. Glad you enjoyed the rework - Gangplank is one of my favorite projects we've released.

> [{quoted}](name=Statikk,realm=NA,application-id=A7LBtoKc,discussion-id=VyuLdWhd,comment-id=001f0000,timestamp=2015-12-18T18:53:01.719+0000)
> 
>I actually had done explorations into completely new R's that actually brought down Cannons (and at one point it summoned what I referred to as the **Pirate Gundam**) that were used to split push and apply global pressure. Unfortunately, we ended up canning all of these ideas for 1 reason or another.
> 

What?! You can't just mention that in passing and not elaborate! Please, describe this "Pirate Gundam" in detail!
 {{sticker:slayer-pantheon-popcorn}}

I used a Super-Sized super minion as a proxy model to prototype the Pirate Gundam. Summoning it was similar to Live R but with a Pantheon R-like feel - delay -> initial drop / explosion -> spawn the Pirate Gundam.

The Pirate Gundam did 2 different things:

1) It fired mid-ranged basic attacks (Cannonballs) from its arms
2) It had a cooldown where it basically did a very delayed and telegraphed version of Malphite's R

I found the Pirate Gundam really fun to play with - it was basically a make-shift Tank for the team. Setting it up to land its Malphite R on enemies by locking them down or forcing them into choke points was always exciting. It was also just fun to follow-up on it if it ever managed to connect with the Malphite R.

That said, it was extremely tank-y and represented a lot of raw power that enemies had to deal with - this made it fairly frustrating to play against since you often felt you were fighting a 1v2, 2v3 or 5v6. It also would have required a ton of art resources to create an entire new model with animations and the such.

We even brainstormed ideas where the Pirate Gundam would detonate barrels for GP or even set him up with interesting barrel patterns for GP to utilize but we never got to test any of that.

Any updates on getting Zyra a new passive?

Also, if Nocturne were to be reworked, which direction would you possibly take him? Seeing as he doesn't really have a niche.
So are you the person to yell at for Stashu getting pulled off of Cass or was that before your time?

This was before my time technically, but I was here when we worked on Cass and all of us are responsible for the Cass rework not just Stashu. We've heard you guys loud and clear on this topic - we're just looking for the right time and opportunity to re-execute on her in a way that hopefully better matches your guys' expectations.

Well I've heard that there's apparently some sort of immobile mage rework space coming up.

Cass seems almost as 'immobile mage' as you can get.
Ghostcrawler posted on ask.fm today or recently that champs that need real work would be left alone during future class updates. - ie not any Morde style half baked reworks in the Mage update

The main champ I want to inquire about is Yorick.  
He has been off the free week rotation for god knows how long, forcing players to buy him on a whim without any chance to try him first, and has been excluded from skins until his "rework," which has been slated practically since he came out.  So my question is, how far along is this rework, and can you comment on how much of his current theme will be staying (shovel, hunchbacked lumbering giant)?  Because aesthetically Yorick is FAR from the worst champ in the game, he is solidly in the middle for visual fidelity.  This rework excuse for the no skins is wearing thin.   

Another quick question, do you have any insight into why it seems like certain champions are tweaked and tweaked and tweaked relentlessly patch after patch until they are where you guys feel they should be?  Examples would be Nidd, Kass, Rengar and Kha off the top of my head.  all of these champs went through what felt like months of every single patch had small changes or full on ability reworks.   From a player point of view, it was annoying to see what seemed like Riot's pet champions of the moment getting change after change where champions like Nocturne for example didn't see a single positive change for over 3 years.

Thanks for your time, you k-pop obsessed b-boy

Yorick is on our current list, but the team is currently more largely focused on Taric. Trust me though, Yorick is definitely on our radar, and I have high confidence we'll ultimately deliver a Yorick we can all be excited about.

I think it's dangerous to do changes to champions simply based on "how long has it been since they've been last touched?" This can be a useful data point that a champion might be out-dated, but it's not necessarily a great sole reason to make a change.

> [{quoted}](name=Statikk,realm=NA,application-id=A7LBtoKc,discussion-id=VyuLdWhd,comment-id=00120000,timestamp=2015-12-18T00:25:21.898+0000)
>
> Yorick is on our current list, but the team is currently more largely focused on Taric. Trust me though, Yorick is definitely on our radar, and I have high confidence we'll ultimately deliver a Yorick we can all be excited about.
> 

Normally, this would be exciting news.  Unfortunately, Meddler had this to say about Yorick a couple of days ago:

> [{quoted}](name=Meddler,realm=NA,application-id=A7LBtoKc,discussion-id=ujXlbawa,comment-id=000c000000020000,timestamp=2015-12-16T05:16:12.754+0000)
>
> Raising and commanding the undead (necromancer or death knight basically) is a pretty strong archetype as far as champion fantasies go, that could offer some really interesting tradeoffs and distinct abilities.

So, I really have to question the Champion Update team's intentions when the head of Gameplay design wants to turn the green, shovel-wielding, minion-controlling brute into Yorick, the generic, stereotypical necromancer of far too many bad D&D games inspired by "Army of Darkness."

I really, really hope you can maintain the uniqueness of Yorick (art, story, etc) and not resort to a complete "Trundling" of my favorite champ.

Happy holidays!
Thoughts on tryndamere? Seems like a good pick for a rework
What lead up to Fiora having %hp true damage on her vitals? Was there no better alternative?

% HP true damage can be annoying to play against, but on the other hand, it allows a champion's damage to be truly agnostic to the target. This is a property of "light fighters" (we need to come up with a better name...) that we feel is critical to their success. They need to be able to actually kill tanky opponents. % HP true damage helps us normalize the damage someone like Fiora deals to both squishy and tanky targets.
Skirmishers.  Call them Skirmishers.  Please.

Yeah, but isn't it also a property of tanks to NOT die?

Like, I'm not saying that tanks need to be unkillable or that someone going full offense shouldn't be able to bring down a tank, but it's immensely annoying at being unable to build against someone. The only attack speed slow on an item is on frozen heart, an item that A) has a lot of mana, making it unappealing for tanks and B) is entirely armor, meaning LW is better against it then most items. You buy it, of course, because you have to, but it doesn't really feel good.

Hell, I'm not even sure if it does a lot against Fiora. I think her Q procs the vitals most of the time.
